-Lmxo9KWp5x59FtmC6IGLQ.text: Pretty nice little place in what seems to be a mostly vacant shopping center. Well kept on the inside, clean, and very friendly staff. I was really excited to try this place, and per the reviews it seemed I should be. I ordered the Mongolian Beef, and I won't say it was bad, but it wasn't very good either. The rice was good, but the meat didn't have much flavor, only spice. For the price I cannot recommend this dish. My co-worker got a shrimp meal for $17, and he was very underwhelmed by the taste as well.   For me, my rating may have been different if I had dined in depending on the service, but having ordered takeout I expected much more for the price, and the raving reviews over this place. I've had much better food at dives than this. Maybe we just chose two dishes that weren't their best.

oJLYftJoHXOBq1Jnk82oUA.text: I called in my order of house fried rice over the phone and it was sitting, waiting for me when I arrived. This restaurant sits over in a shopping center (that doesn't have much shopping). Not hard to find but not a whole lot back there either. Cute little Chinese restaurant. Nothing fancy but not too bad. When I walked in to pick up my order, I checked in on yelp and tried to redeem my egg roll that's offered for checking in. The lady taking my payment absolutely just would not allow it. I asked why. She just kept saying no. I really wasn't trying to make a big deal about the free egg roll. I just wanted to know why she wouldn't accept it. I showed it to her on my phone. Finally she says you have to dine in. Ha. Ok I will sit here and eat my rice. And I still got a no. ok! Whatever! Keep your free egg roll and I'll keep my 5 stars. I mean not that this was a five 5 experience by an means. But the house fried rice was decent. Not the best and not the worse. It did the job for the night. Didn't feel like cooking so it came in handy. Would I order again? Mehhh. I'd try another entree in the future.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States

4JMxWL727JilcMcHMQchwg.text: New Discovery  Szechwan Palace is nestled in the Chinese Cultural Center.  The menu is varied and offers a very good value for lunch specials which include entree, soup, salad, and spring roll.  On this visit to Szechwan Palace, we ate off the Americanized Chinese menu.  The food was very well-spiced, flavorful, and freshly prepared.  We had the Mongolian beef and the Cashew Chicken.  Both dishes hit the spot!  The service was friendly and the decor is modern.  If you ever narrate should stop by and grab a bite to eat you won't be disappointed.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States

xXjlGqY6KnBr_eVOy7_q2Q.text: The food is really really awesome .If you don't order the regular Chinese restaurant item (yes they have those to ) you will get to taste Real Chinese food similar to what u would get in China .... the low rating u find in yelp and Google N other places for this restaurant however (I think ) is for the customer service u get . If u can take  the straight forward customer with a smile u will enjoy some really really amazing food . Just to make it clear ?.your order comes quick ..The water glass is never  empty ...Not bad or nothing but not something u get elsewhere . Like I said it straight forward . Everyone seemed to be enjoying the food  and when food is that good it's ok to focus on food

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Cucumber in Garlic or Spicy Sauce (spicy)
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Interior

XcZt3sp3t3lLWo_q7cWmrA.text: Real, legit, Szechuan! Me being a transplant in Arizona found me yearning for authentic Asian cuisine that's somewhere even remotely close to the caliber I found back home. This hits the mark. To the uninitiated, I can understand why it's not what they expect, but that's because it's REAL and not the whitewashed sugary fried stuff you see everywhere else. I could taste the numbing szechuan peppercorns in my dish, and the attention to texture and technique was  perfecto.   They do have an "Americanized" menu as an option, which, given the demographic here, I get it. I recommend you order the legit stuff. Even if you're new to authentic Chinese Szechuan, you can order the rice noodle with beef, and prepare for a tastebud party.

SP0mq5AhQRvPmmqPIfcZgg.text: This place is just OK but is in a good central location so I frequent often. The service is actually really good! I stick to the basics....fried rice, chow mein, beef n broccoli and orange chicken.  My food is always sizzling hot and made quickly so I appreciate that.  I'm still looking for great Chinese in Phoenix but this is an easy go-to.

qY0NEIAFt8rWKqHqB6INpg.text: Huge menu of both traditional and Americanized dishes. Even includes duck, lamb, intestines, and liver.  I had the (traditional) Cumin Lamb, and the taste was amazing and sort of Mediterranean. Very tender lamb, but the texture was a bit strange. Overall a bit greasy too, which my tummy wasn't crazy about. Lots of other tasty sounding dishes to try though.  Husband had (Americanized) Mongolian Beef. Beef was incredibly tender, and great flavor.  Chicken chow mein was good too. They only serve white rice, not fried or brown.  Great find in Phoenix, we'd definitely eat here again.

CIz_dnQz1i8azd-58fAqSg.text: My Hilton hotel shuttle driver recommended this place. So glad he did as it was great! I ordered the potstickers (pan fried) & the House Chicken. Both were excellent and plentiful. Broccoli comes with the House chicken so I had some vegis. White rice comes with your main dish. Quick friendly service too.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Potstickers &amp; House Chicken.

NFfP0FA2IiA7YKLWBeBJfg.text: Since moving to the valley 5 years ago I've been struggling to find a really good Chinese restaurant. Especially one that sells real Chinese food.  I ordered the dan dan noodles and the pork in sweet been sauce. Both were really good. I didn't know what to expect with either dish but was pleasantly surprised with both. The noodles are spicy but not so much that the other flavors of the dish are hidden. And the sauce used on the pork was very simple but worked well with the perfectly cooked pork.   They have a large menu full of all your American Chinese favorites as well as a lot of traditional foods. The traditional menu seems to focus on foods from Sichuan province but there are lots of recipes from other regions as well, so even if you don't like spicy food, it's worth checking out the Chinese menu!

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Pork in sweet bean sauce and dan dan noodles

ixIqu9kEYlvCMTMoCH3wyQ.text: Never been to the Szechuan restaurant before, surprisingly the food was good and so different than the regular Chinese food.  We had fish and bean curd, sauteed string beans and pork buns ( strangely none of these on the online menu), but they were on the regular menu at the restaurant.  I really like the sauteed string beans, not crazy about the fish and bean curd because there were floating whole cardamom and star anise in the broth and if you accidentally eat them it's taste kind of minty and tangy at the same time, it was ok and my husband liked it. My son liked the pork bun as well. I really want to try something else next time, overall it was good.  When you check if on yelps, you'll get free fried egg rolls.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Free egg rolls with Yelp check in.
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Sautéed string beans was delicious!

YTDJAUsoJtTDrx6XNP7C1w.text: The lunch was cheap but not very good. I ordered the pickle fish noodle  soup lunch. I only ate their fish. I also ordered the lie fan noodle. It was not very good either comparing to what I had in CA.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States

o11vUxR9fbhYRq0OviQzyA.text: Someone please tell me what days to go here so I can get good service.  Reading previous reviews that mention this makes me go HUH?  My friend and I definitely did not experience even mediocre service.  We were seated within a short couple of minutes of waiting.  Our server didn't bother with small talk; went right into "Do you know what you want to order?"  Just like I said in my review with their neighbor Beijing Garden, I can appreciate speedy service for the patrons on their lunch break but service was lacking.  They brought out the wrong order for my friend but it was replaced with the correct one in a reasonable time.  We were never checked up on nor our drinks refilled.  We finished our lunch rather quickly but waited a long time for our check to be brought.  Realizing the time, I went up front to ask for our check and to-go box.  After the time it took to finally pay, we only had 6 minutes to make it back to work on time.  Luckily, we work very very close by and made it back on time.  Like Beijing Garden, this one is another dud.  It's a decent place to satisfy your Chinese food cravings.  However, I don't think I'll be returning.

8vTBC55txVP7YoC_G0xjTA.text: This was the worst food and the worst service I've ever experienced! The food came out exactly 4 minutes after ordering. Was hard as a rock as they had over cooked what was already made. When we asked about other options the waiter told us maybe next time we just shouldn't order the chicken and walked away. It was only after we returned the dishes uneaten that the manager came and asked what we wanted. Additionally, upon receiving the check, the waiter yelled at us to not touch it as we tried to point out how to split the check. Would never step foot in that place again.

NMABAFNVwcwPFkOfOsZBnw.text: This is a gem in Phoenix/Tempee Area.  Just go when they are not busy. Went on a Thursday night and the food was awesome. Went on a weekend night and the food was okay. I recommend ordering the spicy fish.

QS-vuC-f7-2eE2172pAgCQ.text: A decent addition to the chinese food options in Phoenix.  Of course, I went for my usual water-boiled fish.  It was pretty good here, though the numbing flavor that is the norm for this dish was a tad lacking.  String beans were solid.  We also had the cumin beef (usual is lamb, but we weren't feeling in a gamey mood today) and the chongqing chicken, both of which were great.  Oddly, the hot and sour soup was only slightly above average for me - what gives?!  Portion size was also a concern.  Most Szechuan places have huge portions, but we polished things off no problem and had to order a couple more plates...  Price was okay.  Service was also acceptable for me (unlike other Yelpers' experiences).  Would probably go back if I was in the area and had a hankering for Szechuan, though places in Chandler are better if you don't mind heading to the East Valley.

YD-jWVLZ39Q9FP6ImiadRA.text: Being Asian, I judge Chinese restaurants by the service (which isn't great in amazing chinese food restaurants) and whether they speak the language.  Szechwan Palace met both these needs.  I understand the Asian population in Phoenix isn't as huge so they'd need to have the Americanized menu.  The soup was amazing and we even ordered an extra to go.  Anything spicy that you order will be SUPER spicy so be cautious when ordering.  It's authentic enough for me to want to come back here although I haven't tried any other places in the area yet.  I didn't understand the canned Lychee dessert at all, where's the mango pudding or the almond jelly?

BIA6yKoiuNEofblRrPR3Ew.text: This place is the real deal! If your idea of Chinese food is Panda....... You are missing out. Service was fantastic menus is big, but they are quick to help.! I travel to China and Asia frequently and this is the closest you will get in the Valley! Be adventitious and stay away from the Americanized portion of the menu. Enjoy!!!

Jj7NNBRfvHK_hgFQ2-utXQ.text: First I would like to say to everyone that complains about the service is to please stop bitching about it. Yea most of you are stuck in American ways and things should be set in a certain way everywhere. This is a AUTHENTIC Chinese food restaurant, it's not they are being rude or don't want to come back every 2 mins to make sure you are ok it's because there is literally 2-3 waitress's working at a time. I've been here probably 50-60 times since its my fiance favorite Chinese place in phx, and shes from china and hates Americanized Chinese food, but every time I've been here when it's slow or packed I only see 2-3 waitress's and sometimes a helper here and there. So just be patient.   The food is worth the wait if you order correctly. I've had a few americanized dishes and they were ok and my fiance was like you need to order for, the authentic menu and wow I was surprised how Chinese food was suppose to taste like. Alot of the dishes have this weird tingly numbing feeling which is weird at first but you get used to it.   A few things I can remember you should get that we always order, I don't know the Chinese names but I'll try to explain the best I can.   1. Husband and wife dish. It's a app and seved cold. About 7 bucks 2. Boiled fish in spicy sauce.  3. Spicy chicken wings but these are cut in half deep fried then cooked in peppers and spices. My favorite  4. Cucumber dish served cold and has tingly stuff on it. Like 4-5 bucks 5. Pork intestines cooked like the chicken wings above. I know that sounds gross but they taste really good. 6. Beef chow fun, yea this is a americanized dish but it's the best beef chow fun I've had anywhere.   There is a few more but I'm drawing a blank. Anyways this is authentic Sichuan food so explore different dishes because they are GOOD!

3tsSDM_3fzEPpE2okG0XSQ.text: Very good food and I return all the time. I had the beef fried rice and it was great. I only wish they delivered instead of just carry out.

Aieh1DxI3yeFi8QU2CU11Q.text: Best Chinese food in Phoenix I've been coming for years , my favorite dishes are the cucumber and garlic, celery peanut,  pork and bamboo shoot, salt and pepper shrimp ,  I have gotten in a rut and keep ordering my favorites and not tried some Of the more interesting items on the menu.  this place would be great for 8 or 10 people they got big round table with the lazy Susan to try a bunch of dishes .  I would love to see this place to do a monthly tasting event where people sign up in advance and all sit together and try some of the more exotic dishes and the Chef could come out and talk to the group about the meal an preparation . Keep up the good work

c8SF6MsmxmBbDT2td85Uzw.text: Best Chinese food. Order from the Chinese menu version and ask for extra spicy! This place is great!

Ma5BGwDmOpqonlPbURUsoA.text: For those actually from Szechuan like me, this is the most authentic taste I've ever tasted in Phoenix. And it deserves a higher rating.

u2mp_ceiO_-avChDnG4lYA.text: I think that this is the best Chinese restaurants in phoenix, the great taste like home. And not only delicious food, and the service is also very good.

Fq-Ag6_nSo0OZzAL3K_80w.text: Good taste and cost effective lunch, i come to this restaurant twice these two days. Chinese should come and have a try.

gv-H12shhCbeNXAUM0TkgA.text: Service was excellent but food is too salty and not good.  Asian Cafe Express in Mesa is still the best Chinese food in Phoenix Metro. This place is so expensive and not worth it. We had the the spicy tofu, Hunan beef, orange chicken, lamb sizzling plate, Steam bun, pot sticker in chili sauce. Nothing tasted good.  I think 3 of 4 of us had an upset stomach after having the spicy tofu. Definitely not going back.

yCFVvmJNMYxu_CiGGp9T2Q.text: Very pleased!  Authentic menu, GREAT variety!  While I did not order from the Americanized menu, I appreciated the fact that they separated the items so I could ensure I had the authentic cuisine.  I ordered the lamb in spicy black bean sauce on sizzling platter and the pea leaf with garlic sauce...yummmm!!

bchjvQ75jPB1Z0-0Bnmvrg.text: Authentic Chinese food. Even better than most Chinese restaurants in LA. It's a must go place If you live around Phenix and love traditional Chinese food.

tLpuGYWBcJuIrRJeIc4nHA.text: Have been for lunch during the week several times and it was worth putting up with the consistently rude and horrible service for the quick and good and cheap food.     Went today for early Sunday dinner and will not go back.   Service was beyond horrible and food just OK at best.   Also too expensive for what you get.    I don't need to spend thirty dollars to be treated.rude.

vnyGzgUdtYNlorWrckNSvw.text: It's not good, it's fantastic! I recommend getting C74 Squid with Pickled Chili on the menu, it has a good burn to it. The Spring Rolls and Crab Puffs are good as well. They served their food family style, so there is enough for 2-3 people. The price and service is good too.

tlOpsMcHuVMg_6IgRnQ2mQ.text: Just outstanding. The water boiled fish and lamb ribs are especially recommended- just love that numbing pepper!

3vE5cPM9_OCqFQOJT79Uag.text: I occasionally crave Chinese food, but we're in Phoenix...which isn't as culturally diverse as one my think. However! I've been to the Chinese Cultural Center (COFCO) for festivals and shopping.  Szechwan Palace is situation in the foremost corner of the Center.  One can dine in or take out.  Most of the patrons were Asian, which is a good indication that the place serves authentic food.  Don't come with high expectations though, this is not a posh place, by no means.  But the food is delicious! I was able to get a respectable glass of Riesling too.  Service is seriously lacking. The waitresses are in no rush to serve.  I waited over 10 minutes after I was seated for someone to take my drink order. I gave the order for drink and appetizer at the same time. The appetizer came out ten minutes before the drink finally came.  I thought to myself, "this is going to be a loooong evening..."  The good food justifies the long waits. ...I guess.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Happy Family!!!
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Just the beginning... An egg-roll.

Ht_2oQdkD5r-uC9o1P9vzA.text: Yum! I got the lo mein and it was delicious! The restaurant was packed, for good reason.  My only complaint was that the person I went with got her food 10 minutes before me.  I'm not sure if they forgot about my meal, or if it just took longer to make, but it was kind of weird.  Anyways, overall it was a good experience and I would come back.

L73f0mJRvN20yS6jZz-DSg.text: Food was ok. Fried rice excellent. However, service was terrible. Each of our four person party's entrees was delivered 5-10 minutes apart. By the time my son's meal arrived, my mother-in-law had been politely staring at her soup for 20 minutes. Also, staff was rude. Don't recommend.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Kitchen

eqHntCQH64-wkqo0Bpqmlw.text: Delicious food, cheap prices. Would have loved to see the full menu, instead of been limited to the lunch selection.

Iz_3mR2OvRxTOzBSChPiOw.text: Very disappointing.  Food was fairly tasty but cool and service was horrendous.  It took 30 minutes for the waitress to take our order, another 30 minutes for the FIRST entree (twice cooked pork) to arrive, and then DH had to wait another 20 minutes before his General Tsao's chicken came.  So we really didn't get to eat dinner together!  THEN, our appetizer, the steamed buns showed up--after we had finished our meals!  (We thought they had been forgotten, and at that point, we were so disgusted, we didn't say anything.)  Our server was very brusque, hurried, and never made eye contact during the few minutes she allotted us.  What a difference from another server we observed, who was all smiles and worked with the Jewish couple at a nearby table to order in such a way to meet their dietary needs.  We have always liked Szechwan Palace, but we think we'll try Beijing Gardens at the Chinese Cultural Center next time---that's how disappointed we were.

yDvpgjnZoDLs2AyOxzduTg.text: Good chinese food. Luckily they have a few vegetarian options. What put me off this place was the staff. They do not understand what we are trying to tell them. They can understand our orders only if we point at the name. Though it takes a great deal to work in such a setting there is a communication problem. Service is a little slow.

w5_DfHMNUlnYUO9vSCZakQ.text: One word: authentic! I'm from South China and this is the only restaurant in town where I can "fix my cravings"! Wish it's closer to where I live but totally worth the drive. If you are not Chinese, they have "American menus " for Asian fusion dishes.

9TAEBAT-yqSEcmRcuUQJMg.text: I'm giving this restaurant a low rating, because I was very disappointed with the food and service. I ordered the tea rose smoke duck, no flavor. My husband ordered kung poa chicken, no flavor & my friend order curry chicken, very bland. We were told, brown rise was not a dinner option. We were only able to have white rice. Im still searching for a good, no a great Chinese Restaurant in the greater Phoenix metro area. Please follow up if you've experienced a great one. As for Szechuan Palace, I'll pass.

mdZLjPu19DFCMYW5_2nuwg.text: This is my second visit here both trips were equally great. Last night I ordered the Kung Pao Chicken (American version cause I wanted white meat) and it was really good. One thing I liked is they didn't skimp on the chicken like many other places do.  Tonight I got the celery and peanuts appetizer. I had never seen that on any menu and I do like both so I figured WTH. I also ordered the spicy fried filet of fish. I asked the waiter if it was "thai hot" and he said it's very spicy. I'm trying to drop a few pounds so I thought if it's too hot it will help me control my portion.   The celery and peanuts are stir fried with what I think is garlic pit and a tad of salt. I was surprised at how tasty it was and I finished the entire bowl. I waited until my fish arrived and used it as an accompaniment for the fried fish. Now I know the pic makes this fish look hotter that he'll but as long as you're not an idiot and eat the red peppers you will be fine. If you stick to eating the fish and onions I would say it's a 2 out of 10 on the heat scale. Down a few peppers by mistake and well....You can respond and tell me. I know better!  The service was really good except it took a while to get the check. It was packed tonight and only 2 people waiting tables so I won't ding them for it this time.  Give it a try and order off the diner menu #2.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Both together so you can relate the portion size
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Spicy fried fish filet
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Celery and peanuts appetizer

PJaXmNsjYdRKBPpVrewMkQ.text: Not a bad place for lunch. It was reasonably priced, had good service and the food was pretty tasty. It's your standard Chinese fare with $7 lunch specials that come with soup, rice and an egg roll. We had the sesame chicken, sezchuan shrimp and dumplings in spicy broth. All these things were good EXCEPT for the stupid salad with ranch dressing that comes on the side.....while I appreciate the salad, I wouldn't really call an iceberg and ranch dressing salad "authentic" like the restaurant advertises.

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Dumplings in spicy broth
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Egg drop soup
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Sesame chicken

j9MiVEvhZGtLW2geeEW-vQ.text: I've been looking for real Szechuan food in the valley for many months. I feel like I finally found perfect and authentic Szechuan Chinese restaurant for me! We wanted to have none menu food but they made it special for us. It was very pleasant. :)

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Garlic sauce bak choi with dried mushroom
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Hotpot
Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Snow pea leaves

jlFL9sM4HIJ_C209tAxNiQ.text: Started with a beer and a few in our group had soup, and before we knew it our meals arrived! Wow, fast service and deliciously hot food...I especially loved my Kungpao Chicken which had plenty of heat from the chiles. Huge servings and so we shared our meals with one another. Our group enjoyed talking with each other and probably would have ordered 1-5 desserts, but instead we received our bill and fortune cookies. But anyway, we sat and talked while they continued to be sure our water glasses were filled. When visiting here, be sure to check the outdoor display of Hanghou and Suzhou which is part of the Chinese Cultural Center; provides a nice short walk to read the historical info or to sit quietly at the small pond. In the area there is a supermarket for everything. I shop there each time I eat at one of the establishments here.

iqLizchdD0CHftUK7uEkWw.text: My lunch experience stands at 2.5 stars. My introductory question for you: Cheap and Fast vs. Quality?  They have decently sized lunch portions including soup, small salad, veggie spring roll and choice of brown or white rice. The Beef with Broccoli was just ok, but for the price, I couldn't complain. The sauce with pretty thick, which I mixed into the rice for a pleasant consistency. One of my coworkers got the "average tasting" House Chicken, and another had the Shrimp with Lobster Sauce. Not only did we literally receive the bill before it arrived, she was terribly unhappy with the seafood quality and flavor. Her Diet Coke didn't show up till the end either - producing more sour reviews on her part.  My "veggie soup" consisted of a piece of broccoli, three carrots and an onion slice soaked in wonton broth. Go with the egg drop instead.  I will mention that we were already grossly disappointed having learned the Golden Buddha was closed and it's hard to compete with them. For a quick, low budget Chinese food experience with a decent ambiance, Szechwan Palace is an option, but not a GREAT one.

rpkNdfcp_hVQAP5e3IryIA.text: Just had their water boiled spicy beef and traditional fried rice. Loved them both! The beef was tender and had just the right amount of spice. The rice was fresh and not greasy like most Chinese food joints. I also had the the spring rolls and they were just ok. I didn't give them the full 5 stars because although the service was fast, they weren't as attentive as i would have liked them to be. Overall the food was superb!

photos.caption: Photo of Szechwan Palace - Phoenix, AZ, United States. Water Boiled Spicy Beef and Traditional Fried rice....to the dome!

1g7sIX0bVM3f6ov2DvxUAg.text: Okay, people. There are NOT a lot of good Chinese restaurants in the state of Arizona. I know this because I have tried almost all of them in search of finding something equivalent to the restaurants in California.  Szechwan Palace is the best place I have eaten at in this entire state so hooray for them!! I LOVE LOVE their pickled cabbage. It is ridiculous spicy and that just makes me extremely happy. You MUST get their Chinese menu (I think they have a different Chinese and American menu for people who are not used to eating traditional Chinese food). Their spicy cumin lamb is soo good. Actually, I've gotten a lot of dishes there and haven't really been disappointed by anything during dinnertime.  Warning - during lunch, I think their lunch specials are only American-Chinese food which consists of orange chicken and broccoli beef which really does not represent how good the food is. Go for dinner and experience the real Chinese food :)

-qjQ4le0eiqLIpyn4TMwzA.text: This place is like family. One of the rare Szechwan styled restaurants in the valley. If you have never had this style you have to try it. Really fresh.

ig0dGxszW5ao7dHtVTjtgA.text: This was my first time at SP. We waited about 15 min after being seated before someone came to take our order. We were never offered or asked if we wanted anything to drink. We started with pot stickers and egg roles then continued with orange chicken. After ordering, the pots tickers came right out and tasted old and deep fried when the menu said pan fried. Within 2 minutes after getting the appetizer our entree came out. It really worries me when food comes out that fast. All the food tasted old and refried and the fried rice was mushy.  The service was not good and no one came back to check on us or to refill our drinks. The waited disappeared and the only reason we got boxes or a check was because the busser  saw me looking around for service.   We will probably not return.

pR8apy4GlNmTMoTBoTtbbQ.text: I gave it 2 stars only because they didn't provide an authentic Chinese food to me. Named a Sichuan palace but taste like Panda Express. If it's a Panda Express I would have given this place at 3 stars.

9Bo_LtP4d0iOnSHibb-jbA.text: Great food!  We had the home made dumplings in chili oil, Kung pao chicken, and a pork dish.  The dumplings were incredible, but the Kung pao was the best I have ever had.  People were waiting outside to eat here.  We will definitely eat there again.

N2YKpI6JUG6Vyntf5ZokKA.text: If you are a Panda Express lover, you can go ahead and cross this place off your list.  This is authentic china food (See Eddie Lacy).  When you can find pork intestine and see whole ducks in the kitchen you know you are at a place that knows what they are doing.   The hot pot options are all delicious, the classic Mongolian beef is very good as well.  The tea tree mushroom hot pot is I think the most delicious item they have.  You cannot go wrong here on really anything you order!

Kvk-ZgWhnky_DV4kZgEM9Q.text: This is one of the main restaurants at the COFCO center located next to the Asian supermarket. We live down the street and decided to try this place. We really like the eggplant and pork and string bean dishes. It is Szechuan food so they have a decent variety of spice if you like the tongue numbing spice. It is pretty authentic and we come here from time to time. It's best for sharing so order a few plates and grab some friends.

04Utj6VYy5T0hCHFKnuTQA.text: Had the water boiled seafood combo, way over seasoned, could not finish the dish, i tasted like a bowl of chloraseptic, mixed with hot sauce.... i like spicy food, but im pretty sure some insane person in the kitchen lost their mind when they made my dish ...

1klT55tJlSDc-I9ViNqIRg.text: Today, I visited this place after not having been here for quite some time. The place use to not have all that many customers, but today (Sunday) the place was very busy for lunch. Despite being busy, they took our orders very quickly and we were served in under 10 minutes. A problem that I had with Szechwan Palace in the past was that despite the price of around $10.00 for a plate (entree) the portions were small and kind of stingy. But today, was very different. The portions were large and everyone at our table of 5 was able to eat with contentment from all five of our orders; the flavor was really good in my opinion. Rice here is free which is a must for a spicy place.  Lastly, I'd like to say that I really enjoy ice water. Some places seem to be so stingy with their water. Today, four glasses. Awesome. I'll be now visiting this place regularly.  My favorite: C36. Yu Xiang Pork Sliced pork stir-fried with wood ears, celery and bamboo shoots in yuxiang flavor (spicy) C50. Beef with Onions  Beef stir fried with yellow onion and scallion.

nIh3vU6NvKMfb8DfvNznPQ.text: If you order from the Chinese Menu and not the American Chinese Menu items your food might be TONGUE Thrilling Spicy and your mouth might get numb.  We got started with the Sauteed Spicy Cucumbers. They were so crispy spicy and refreshing and were a nice start. I had the water boiled chicken and it WAS THE SPICIEST FOOD I EVER HAD IN MY LIFE. It was SO SPICY I felt High and my head was flooded with Euphoria. My mouth went numb. I had this dish twice here before once with chicken and once with fish and neither time before was it this kind of spicy. It really was too spicy for me this time so I took home my leftovers and will thin it down for latter. The chicken in this dish was tender like no other place makes chicken. This really was an experience.  Our waiter highly recommended the hot spicy beef with pickled vegetables. The beef was very good and very tender like the chicken was and it also was a spicy dish but at a more comfortable level.  Portions were large and generous.  Service was pleasant (this time) but you only drink water unless you order a beer.  They don't clear your plates when you are done either.  It's an experience!

Y_FN9oCDRtcuL-g0g6rYSg.text: Good and tasty food. The food is freshly made to order. Vegestables are fresh crunchy. The place smells clean and looks clean.

f-Ip1Ep4unNknLArJKP_CQ.text: Went there for lunch on 9/6/2013.  When we walked in the man at the front desk seemed uninterested and told us to seat ourselves.  We started to settle into a spot but got interrupted by a waitress who then seated us. Make up your mind people.  Menus came fast but without a drink order, we were both very thirsty as it was over 100 out side.  We also had to wait a bit long for the food order.  The staff seemed to pointedly ignore us and walk past our table again and again.  Our waitress eventually came to check on us but was so intent on speedily asking a quick question she started to walk away without a drink order again, we had to stop her.    Food came promptly, with our drinks, but it tasted so so at best, about take out quality.  We chugged through the waters and soda very quick but the empty glasses sat at the edge of the table until we finally had to hold up an empty glass and yell over for someone to bring refills. Rude yes, but nothing else got any kind of attention.    After we were done, yep you guessed it, waited forever for the check.  No excuse for a place with people at only 10% of the tables.  Another big issue:  They have a yelp coupon for checking in, even though it was presented at time of ordering, they WOULD NOT HONOR IT!!  Bad service, so so food and dishonest representation.  And we had been trying to get there for a long time.   At least it was cheap.  Update:  We were contacted by the manager regarding the coupon not being honored.  They said it was only for the dinner service.  Problem is, the coupon did NOT state that.  This makes it False advertising and constitutes fraud in my book.  Its called "bait and switch" draw them in with a False ad.  That only makes me feel worse about this place, can I take the one star back?

JuuWxy1kNsK3w7CP1jBTGA.text: Went there for authentic Chinese food. Was not disappointed. Got the cumin lamb water boiled fish kung pao chicken and orange chicken. Awesome fish...kung pao was good too. The lamb flavor was good they can improve the quality of lamb. The texture was just not there. Or they can make an effort to make it crisper.  Overall good. But won't go again as lamb was not on the spot.

KObHidUvU1hPbPI_7fAM_w.text: A vendor from my job took us out to this place and I'm grateful he did! I have been here once a week since then. The water boil fish and the chongping chicken are phenomenal!

IrRdnuQUZ50XWtWeMvdh2g.text: First time here during my vacation here! Looking for authentic Chinese food, read reviews about this place, sounds very authentic. Good food and services. Didn't wait long for food! :)

HoigWYd7YXweg9nwHqlD-w.text: The poor Szechwan peppercorn used to get a bad wrap. For the unfamiliar its not even related to the black peppercorn, for the familiar its spice properties can be quite magical. Actually the dried berry husk from the prickly ash tree, the USDA banned the peppercorn from 1968-2006. The peppercorn was seen as a hazard due to the potential of carrying citrus canker, a harmful bacteria to citrus crops. The process of heating them to 160 degrees kills any possible bacteria thus lifting the ban. Szechwan Palace, located in the Chinese Cultural Center, celebrates this daily. If you've ever tasted such dishes as Ma Po Tofu or Kung Poa Chicken, then you've had Szechwan cooking before.  The funny thing about these peppercorns is that they're not even really that spicy. At first the flavor might have a certain peppery pungency that gives way to more of a citrus like aftertaste. Though here's the kicker, as you eat them you might feel your tongue start to tingle then eventually go slightly numb. This sensation is strangely addictive, like getting a shot of Novocain; it might just leave you drooling over your plate.  For the unadventurous Szechwan Palace does serve your standard type Chin-American food like egg rolls and pork fried rice, but this isn't a strong point. Id skip those items and go right for the more unique dishes, be sure to ask for the full menu rather than the standard "best of" version.  Being a fan of offal and other not so famous cuts of beef, I ordered up the #3 Beef Tendon in Spicy Sauce ($6.95). Fresh cilantro and chewy slices of tendon are mixed with peppercorn oil were a hit. I know that dish isn't for everyone but trust me, its tasty. By contrast the #9 Spicy Cucumber ($3.95) is a little more approachable with cool pieces of raw cucumber seasoned with peppercorns and dried chilies.  There are a slew of dishes titled "water boiled" though none that I have tried seem to be in water. Instead you get a luxurious sauce filled with peppercorns, vegetables and meat or fish. This outing included the #18 Water Boiled Beef ($9.95), fork tender strips of beef in a velvety pepper spiked sauce made my tongue sparkle then go numb. Like I said, these peppercorns are magical.  My absolute favorite dish was the #98 Rice Cake ($7.95). The thin chewy disks of rice noodles, ground pork and cabbage were bathed in a slightly sweet and smoky sauce was craveable.   When ordering the Special Cumin Lamb with Bone ($11.95), Id venture to say that they use the word lamb loosely. The difference between a lamb and a sheep is age and this directly reflects the flavor of the meat. The younger lamb is sweet and tender where sheep aka mutton tends to be extremely gamy and tough, these were definitely the later. No amount of fragrant cumin could cover the extreme gaminess of the meat. This may have been isolated since on a previous visit the dish was exceptional.  With over 100 choices on the menu plus daily specials, Szechwan Palace brings a whole new level of spice, even if it does numb your tongue.

yuZQWBVI6Dt-kYZ5Q7NyNA.text: My family's been coming to this place for years, and it used to be one of my favorite restaurants! Then we heard their head chef left a few years ago, and the quality wasn't as good anymore. Nevertheless, we were in the area last week and decided to try them out again. Came for dinner, and the place was pretty full! (Although, apparently the other restaurants in the plaza had closed down so it could just be due to lack of choice).   We ordered our usual dishes, and they were still pretty good! The only disappointment was the cold noodles: They were pretty flavorless, and completely different from before. But the Chongqing Chicken (Bone-In) was still crispy and flavorful! However, the portion was much smaller than in the past. Another favorite of ours is the stir-fried green pepper potato strips, which didn't disappoint. Overall a solid spot to go for some authentic Szechwan cuisine.

l1_FK0-DBV9w1befZs4aQw.text: This place used to be excellent but is now mediocre at best. Maybe they changed ownership. Don't bother.

Nq3nvYGN4Y8HMp52miPL0g.text: Date of Visit, 8/8, Approximately 12pm  Szechwan Palace is very good.  They split their menu into authentic dishes & American dishes.  This place was recommended to me by one of the numerous Uber drivers that I have had on this trip.  I ordered the Kung Pao Chicken, & let me tell you, the plate with the chicken & the pot with the rice were huge!  I actually was not able to finish mine order, but I will definitely recommend this to anyone coming to Phoenix.  No stars lacking as the servers appeared to be very attentive.

_ocimtff47eU3Wy4O2x9nA.text: The name of this restaurant is too big for its britches. I had pretty good expectations for this place since many of my coworkers highly recommended it.  I went during my lunch, there wasn't much of a wait as it appears most patrons opt to dine in. Customers have the ability to call in or take out, which I did. It was nice to see that they had great pescetarian and vegan options which gave me a multitude of options. I decided on the lunch special of honey walnut shrimp and fried rice. It comes with your choice of egg roll, soup or salad for a little under $10. I waited for about 10 mins for my order and headed back to work.  Presentation: I wasn't impressed. There was literally two scoops of rice (as if they'd used an ice cream scooper) that had no veggies whatsoever. My honey walnut shrimp(5 medium sized pieces) lay atop a small bed if coleslaw???strange (of all the foods you can lay shrimp on) there was also about 6 walnuts as well.   Taste:  The dish not only lacked color and presentation but flavor sadly. The worst part of all is I actually caught myself saying in my mind (of course) that even Panda Express tasted better! I don't know, maybe it was my order or maybe this "palace" serves pauper plates served up by employees just as so-so as the food.  In conclusion the employee I came in contact with neither the food was downright horrible. The prices on the menu don't match the quality of food and that is the sole reason I won't make another visit here. Who knows, maybe in the future they'll make their way to the Ranch Market and pick up a few spices.

03PPxF2A5psSA4ND0zbH6Q.text: Searched for this place via Yelp and saw that it had many reviews (over 150) and decent ratings, so my friend and I decided to try it out.   Overall the 2 stars is due to the HORRIBLE service received. Great service is very important to me and even with good food, bad service makes it not enjoyable. I will give the short version:  Walked in, host seating us without any greeting. Waitress was somewhat nice at first- I could tell they were busy, but some attention would have been nice. Ordered our food, and my friend got his food in about 10 minutes. 20 minutes later I still had no food and when I asked, they hadn't even started. Guess it's not a good idea to ask because after this, my plate was literally thrown down at me and the grease from my sizzling plate kept splashing up. From then on, I did not even bother asking for anything further from the ladies who were in a cranky mood.   However, they aren't going to get 1 star because the food was very good. I really wish I could have enjoyed more, but all I wanted to do was leave.

c9NvdOZ-WcFZwVI1sipdNg.text: Last year, Szechwan Palace restaurant in the Chinese Cultural Center Phoenix, AZ was our most favorite authentic Asian restaurant. I would have given it 5 stars then. We heard that the Chinese Cultural Center was sold and is closing, so when we came back this year, we called and were told that Szechwan Palace was still open and they don't plan to move!   Consequently, we rushed right over for dinner last week.  What a sad place to see the entire Chinese Cultural Center with vacant shops, all except for Szechwan Palace.  The wait staff seemed somber, as well, and did not seem to care if we received good service.  We ordered our food and found it to be below par from when we were there last year.  One of our party ordered a lamb dish that is completed by cooking it at the table on a hot pan.  When the waitress brought it, she threw the hot mess onto the even hotter metal platter causing very hot oil to be thrown all over the man who ordered it ruining his clothing and all over the tabletop.  But instead of reacting to his screams or trying to clean up the mess, she just walked away!!  We had to repeatedly ask for help and the wait staff just stood there stone faced not cleaning up anything.  Finally, after we complained for the 4th time, our waitress said she would check with her boss who then gave us 10% off the check.  Luckily, the hot grease hit his clothing and not his skin.  Otherwise, it would have been a terrible thing. But, like I mentioned, no one there seemed to care.  I ordered Kung Pow Chicken that had so many chopped red hot peppers that one could not see the peanuts in the dish.  It was so spicy hot that I could not eat it and switched with hubby who can tolerate that kind of heat in food.  As an appetizer, we ordered crab puffs that were overcooked just to the point of almost being burnt.  The restaurant was packed that Saturday evening with perhaps 75% Asian patrons.  There is an American menu for those who like things less spicy and a Chinese menu which is served differently.  The prices are reasonable.  I really hope that this restaurant can find a new home or survive where it is so that the employees can be happy once again and the cooks can turn out the authentic Chinese food we have loved here in the past.

qWx31GrtPuPGlnZO7xR43g.text: I used to hate studying, but one must study the massive menu before placing an order.  There are 2 Menus in one. Dishes that start with an A are the gringo dishes, Kung pow xxx mu shu vegetables etc. Then there dishes that start with a C, this means a dish unaltered from china. In come cases this means unusual ingredients like pork kidney, or just copious amounts of peppers as with the seczuan dishes.   Being veg it took a bit of time to tease out dishes that were meat free and still had flavor but we managed a decent array, however I really want to go back and try some of the more exotic dishes and see if they can be made meat free.   While the food is good, they may have a bit less service than the number of tables need so don't expect white glove service. But at these prices $6-8 for most dishes who cares.

_iDM5pDOISqG2AMcODBD_g.text: They apparently don't have orange chicken (even though it's on the menu) so they suggested "Spicy Chicken" instead. The dish was literally 75% peppers and 25% chicken. It was inedible. I won't be ordering there again.

7XD6PcFLbM2-ZFBNJbUBTQ.text: Worst services of all time. The old Chinese woman server has mental issues and argue with the guest.

YFmEaUjRHNAeN3KJsB-rsw.text: I am originally from Szechwan and I'm glad that they do offer quite authentic Szechwan dishes (at least compared to other Chinese restaurants in the valley). The spiciness and the seasoning are just right. The place is clean and the servers are okay. Try not to order from the Americanizd Chinese food menu and try some authentic Chinese food! You will be surprised.

xhN4mWKJjZkLPc9Dsmgkpg.text: Had the duck and frog legs. The frog legs were ok, but the duck was disgusting. the last bite I took tasted like soap and I had to spit it out. I'm not one to stop eating when I'm hungry.

Y4ek_SyJvHzOVQG3zCpp7w.text: This place had decent reviews.  Decent is a gratuitous word for this restaurant.  I had DanDan Noodles, House Special Chicken and House Special Fried Rice.  DanDan Noodles were good.  A bit plain but good! Deserves a star by itself!  House Special Chicken was decent.  Large plate.  House Special Fried Rice.  Horrible!  Rice was too wet and laden with MSG. Not salty but you know that 'salty taste' that lasts 30 minutes later?  MSG.  This is the main reason why I gave this place 2 stars.

9TDgX2VdtpEHR-5k-ecwlg.text: Here is the deal.  You have to ask for the Chinese menu.  I am not saying this is right but if you are anything other than Chinese, they will hand you the "American" menu.  DO NOT GO THERE!!  Ask for the Chinese menu.  This is the BEST Chinese restaurant that I have eaten at in the states.  I lived in China for a year and this is Truely authentic western China food.  I spent a couple months in Sichuan province in the west and you are getting exactly what is served there.  Try the "yu xiang rou si" literally translated, fish smelling small pieces of meat.  It is julienned pork in a wonderful sauce that DOES NOT  have any fish flavor or smell at all.  It is SO good.  One of my favs.  Also try the julienned potato with green pepper, wonderful!!  Ma Po Dou Fu is very traditional of the Sichuan province and known all over the country.  These guys make it right using the star anise which gives heat and a numbing quality of the mouth.  If this happens, it is authentic.  You will know what I mean when you have it.  Sichuan food is a bit oily which is authentic, a chile oil to warm them, since in the west up in the mountains that lead up to Tibet (known as the Gateway to Tibet) where the winters are very cold.

Ra9ju9OEPTQuSEolh0nngw.text: There are two ways to rock the Szechwan Palace:  1.  The small menu and a fork, 2.  The larger menu and some chopsticks.  You will likely be profiled upon entry and, unless you're Chinese, get a fork.  On my first venture to the SP, I didn't let my lack of chop slow me down.  Since the specials were off limit to us because they were "in Chinese" I ordered the water boiled fish.  As mentioned in other reviews, the sauce miraculously changes the way other foods (including water) taste and should be experimented with at length.  It isn't so much spicy as it is transcendental.  On my second venture, a friend snagged us some respect by grabbing the Chinese menu.  We liked the squid with pickle, missed out on the water boiled eel but settled for more of the fish, and really loved the baby bok choy with mushrooms.  It is best to end a meal here with some of the fine corn jelly candies at the Ranch Market next door.

_mw6ocDzUvm66ngg-1ad-g.text: My experience here this past weekend was mediocre at best.  I arrived at the Chinese Cultural Center at about 4pm, after Dim Sum had ended at the Golden Buddha, so I decided to give this place a try with my Taiwanese boyfriend and visiting family.  The prices were a bit of a rip off for the portions that were served.  I order the vegetarian chow fun for $1 extra than it would have been as "chow mein."  I'm assuming we just received the American menu, but who knows?  The service was conducted half in English and half in Chinese, which is typical when our mixed race party shows up at a Chinese restaurant.  I sampled the lemon shrimp my father ordered.  The sauce was a bit too sugary, like lemon drops, and the shrimp itself had such a thick, hard shell of batter that it was hard to taste the shrimp.  No drinks were suggested; we were left with only the water that was refilled every 5 minutes.  When we boxed up some leftovers, they did not give us the rice to take home, which makes me wary that it is being re-used.  A child was with us, and there was no kid's menu, which was a bit of a disappointment.  The food overall tasted alright, but I have definitely had better (and better service too!)  Nice try, but I'll stick with the Golden Buddha or something closer to Chandler.

fNrw_KzYp246GOm1FPkzHg.text: I would have to say  that Szechwan Palace in the Chinese Cultural Center has to be the best Chinese Food that I've had in Phoenix & I've eaten at a lot of different Chinese restaurants over the years... All of the entrees were very flavorful, & came out of the kitchen piping hot in a timely manor, The servers were helpful , pleasant, & very polite. Now for the most attractive part of this dining experience... The amount of delicious food the my friend Michael & I got for just under $30 (The House Combo for 2) was astonishing. For that price we got hot  green tea to keep us warm, 6 pot stickers, 2 spring rolls, 2  full entrees, a big bowl of sizzling rice soup a huge plate of house fried rice with chicken shrimp & pork in it, & to top it all off a bowl full of sweet lychee fruits for desert. Lets just say I will be frequenting the establishment in the near future. For all you out there on yelp or Facebook in the Phoenix area that wanna try this restaurant out it is located in the Chinese Cultural Center on 44th St. & Cofco Dr. just south of the loop 202.

HEBPD5LMBuAD5GNNMOF8Vw.text: Fabulous flavorful, food with a great balance of heat, spice and complex flavors.  I ordered "off menu" their Szechwan cucumbers which were fresh, crisp, slightly salty with a great hot oil and many red chilies tucked into the dish.  I added a little of the table chili sauce to compliment the heat already in the dish and it was a great appetizer.  I ordered the Water Boiled Beef ... even though it came with a warning to "some customers" that it might be too spicy and oily ... and it was delivered bubbling hot with lovely slices of cooked beef and vegetables in a wonderful stock with a chili oil and pepper flavor that was perfectly balanced.  Heat, taste and a great texture all combined for a really wonderful entree.  This is a spicy dish without a doubt, but the warning is unwarranted as it allows the great flavors to come through and when combined with the generous portion of rice served, it is a perfect meal.  My waiter Paul was very excited about the dish and when he found out I had liked it so much, he promised to make me a "special dish", not on the menu next time I come in.  That will be very soon!!  The "Chinese Menu" is more complex as are the specials on the board coming in.  I am looking forward to another meal here shortly to keep sampling this well executed food at Szechwan Palace.
